title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Yennel, which is steep, declining to the south-west, and le.ics to a lower street, which is far larger than the high chiefe street, and it runs t'rom the Kirkland to the Well Trees, in which there have been many pretty buildings, belonging to the severall gentry of the countrey, who were wont to resort thither in winter, and divert themselves  in converse together at their owne houses.

title: Essays of travel and in the art of writing,
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: There be four lanes which pass from the principall street ; one is called the Black Vennel, which is steep, declining to the south-west, and leads to a lower street, which is far larger than the high chiefe street, and it runs from the Kirkland to the Well Trees, in which there have been many pretty buildings, belonging to the severall gentry of the countrey, who were wont to resort thither in winter, and divert themselves  in converse together at their owne houses.

title: The lilac sunbonnet :
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " Or members o' session," said sleeky Garment of the Kirkland, who had twice escaped the stool of repentance on the ground that, as he urged upon the body, " gleds [hawks] shouldna pike gleds een oot."

title: The lilac sunbonnet :
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " Weel, sir, ye see the way o't was this : I was thinkin' to mysel', ' There's twa or three ways o' takin' the bulks intil the pulpit — There's the way consequential — that's Gilbert Prettiman o' the Kirkland's way.

title: Lilac Sunbonnet
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: " Or members o' session," said sleeky Carment ofthe Kirkland, who had twice escaped the stool ofrepentance on the ground that, as he urged upon thebody, "gleds shouldna pike gleds een out."
